Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2013 12:00PM PaigeH wrote: Thanks April and MMowl.  April, the increased number has me quite worried as well.  And Mmowl, I am very much looking forward to my first appointment with my surgeon, who is one of the best in the state.  It seems like she is in close communication with the radiologists.  I had my biopsy today and when I mentioned that I had an appointment with her, the radiologist perked up.  She said she would try to get my results by tomorrow so that my surgeon could fit me in Saturday if possible. Had the biopsy early this morning, and having trouble getting the bleeding to stop.  It's still leaking a bit.  But I tend to be a bleeder.  They only needed four samples, and I saw the sample scans.  They definitely got the microcalcs in there. So now the wait begins.   Any advice on how to handle holiday parties?  Some are with acquaintances, some with dear friends.  I am not very good a putting on a poker face, and I am finding hard to engage in mild chit chat, as these things require.
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 05:22PM PaigeH wrote: Got my results - - calcifications benign, and pathology shows radial scar.  So relieved.  Radiologist said all that was needed was follow up mammogram in 6 months.  Surgeon said they may want to remove the radial scar to be sure, but they will get back to me after they have the full pathology report. Thanks everyone, for the support! Star13, hoping for similar results for you!
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 04:50AM PaigeH wrote: Yes Marie, thank you.  I am very hopeful that if it is something, it is early stage.   Star13, I admire your ability to put it off until after the holidays.  Waiting would make me nuts.  I know I will be calling the radiologist by 2:30 if I have not heard anything yet, and it is only now 24 hours since the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2013 06:03AM PaigeH wrote: Thanks Holeinone. Fortunately I have really good insurance, so I don't need to worry about that, at least not so far. My biopsy has been scheduled for Thursday morning at 7 am. They squeezed me in - - they seemed concerned about the results. So did the surgeon's office. She said to keep in touch about results and they would fit me in this Saturday if necessary, even though they are booking out to mid-January for the doctor I want. The radiologist referred to all of the v-shaped calcifications as like a "flock of geese flying south for the winter." I need to stop googling things. V-shaped = scary. Good luck with your radiation. My friend just finished hers and said it was so much better than the chemo.
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: PaigeH wrote: So, how worried should I be? I had a Birads 3 report six months ago after a diagnostic mammo. The doctor said she recommended waiting six months and retesting, or if I wanted they could do a biopsy. I waited. Went in today. I knew it was not good when I was waiting, and waiting, and waiting for results, as other women came and went. The tech finally showed up and said the radiologist wanted to see me. Longest walk of my life. Radiologist was super nice - - too nice. I didn't give him any reason to think I was freaking out, but he sat me down and kept his hand on my arm the whole time he was talking to me and showing me my films. He said there were "significant" changes since the last test was done. Must have said that 3 or 4 times. He said the calcifications are showing a branching or casting pattern, shaped like ducts. He said biopsy was a must, but that it is a small area, so we "caught it early." When I pressed about what chance of cancer, he said 15%, but that is contrary to everything I have read since about fine linear branching calcifications. He said Birads 4 now, but according to what I have read it should be a 4b or 4c, more specifically. Sooo, anyone know of anyone who has had fine linear branching calcs that were benign? And, does the fact that the number of calcifications has increased "significantly" increase my odds of malignancy? Radiologist said to have my GYN call in an order for the stereotactic biopsy. GYN said she doesn't do that, she refers to a breast surgeon and lets them make the decision. I don't want to wait to meet with a surgeon just for her to refer me to the radiologist for the biopsy anyway. Is it better to have testing done by a radiologist or a breast surgeon? If it's all the same, I just want whatever will get me the fastest results. A very good friend just finished chemo and rads for breast cancer. I know what this does (as much as you can second hand). Very scared. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 05:24PM PaigeH wrote: Oh, and just to clear up the calcifications issue: radiologist who did the biopsy disagreed with the characterization of the calcifications as "fine linear branching."  She thought they were better described as "amorphous and clustered."  That also fits with the radial scar dx.
Posts.Title: Fine linear branching calcs, increased in number PaigeH marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 06:38AM PaigeH wrote: Thanks everyone.  So hopefully, the angle explains it.  It still seems coincidental to me that the initial lesion was at 6:00, and the biopsy was at 6:00, but the new lesion was at 3:00.  And all of my soreness is at 6:00, none at 3:00.  I hope they did not get confused and take from the wrong spot.  I will see what they have to say when (if?) they get back to me today, and if they don't I will call the breast surgeon.
Posts.Title: Biopsy in the wrong spot? PaigeH PaigeH

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2013 08:09AM PaigeH wrote: Radiologist called, she said that 3:00 was the same as 6:00 for them, just from a different perspective.  In any case, she assured me that they did get the biopsy from the second area of concern, not the old area of concern.   I am satisfied with this answer. MK, I am not sure I would be satisfied with that explanation.  Did you discuss it with a surgeon?
Posts.Title: Biopsy in the wrong spot? PaigeH PaigeH

Posts.Content: PaigeH wrote: So I started a thread last week describing my 6 month mammogram findings, which were "fine linear branching calcifications.  Several new calcifications (since last mammo)."  As noted in that thread, I went for my biopsy, and they said it was a radial scar with amorphous (not fine linear branching) calcifications.  I just got the pathology report, and now I think they did the biopsy in the wrong spot. My original mammogram, 6 months ago, noted an area of concern with heterogeneous microcalcifications at 6:00 (location on breast).  My follow up mammogram results, last week, showed the new calcifications at the anterior third (front third) of the breast at 3:00.  But the biopsy was done not at 3:00, where the new calcifications were, but at 6:00, where the old ones were!  The biopsy wound is at 6:00, and the biopsy report said the biopsy was taken from 6:00.  I only put it all together after getting the path report and comparing it to the mammo reports. I have a call in to the radiologist's office, but they are taking an uncharacteristically long time to call back.   When you all had biopsies, did they go in at an extreme angle (as would be required to reach a spot at the front of the breast at 3:00 from an entry at 6:00)?  Or just straight in from the skin to the wound? If they did this wrong I am not going to be a happy camper! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy in the wrong spot? PaigeH PaigeH

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 07:42AM PaigeH wrote: The waiting is the hardest part.  The likelihood is that if it is something, they caught it early.  Hang in there, keep yourself busy and distracted as much as possible.  And don't worry about the biopsy, it isn't bad at all!
Posts.Title: Scared and worried about pending biospy shellbell1963 PaigeH

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 10:51PM PaigeH wrote: Thanks to you both for responding.  I would like to be reassured by the Birads 3, but I think something is making me have doubts about the classification.  Everything I have read is if there are significant changes, it should be a 4.  That's what they look for after 6 months, right?  And frankly, I was just really not impressed with the radiologist when I met her.  She was totally unable to explain why the significant changes she pointed out did not warrant a higher classification.  Maybe I will have another radiologist look at my pictures, for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: Birads 2 to Birads 3? PaigeH PaigeH

Posts.Content: PaigeH wrote: Hi all, I am sure this will turn out to be nothing, but I would love some input.  I had a mammogram 2 years ago that showed calcifications in left breast that were determined to be b9, so I was given a Birads 2.  Just had another mammogram and was called back for diagnostic.  Diagnostic shows more calcifications in left breast than 2 years ago, some of which were described as "heterogeneous," which was new.  Others were milk of calcium and round, which I know are typically b9.  Distribution was described as "regional", but the radiologist showed me the films and when pointing out some of the calcifications, said that were some that were clustered and some coalescing.  I was given a Birads 3 this time.  My question is, if there were significant changes from my last mammogram to this one, isn't that inherently suspicious and warranting a biopsy? I am someone who does my research, so I went into the diagnostic mammogram with a pretty good idea of the issues to ask re: calcifications (morphology, size, pattern, etc.).  Frankly, I did not have a lot of faith in the responses I got from the radiologist.  She seemed a bit frazzled in answering the questions.  She said I could have a biopsy if I want one.  Well, I don't want one if I don't need one, but I do want to have a little more reassurance that, given the changes from 2 years ago, I don't need one. Is it typical to have significant changes in calcifications that turn out the be b9?  I did some research and couldn't find a concrete answer, just answers to the question of what happens if there are not changes.  Thanks for any info! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Birads 2 to Birads 3? PaigeH PaigeH
